title: In Kosovo, Ukrainians train in mine clearance
description: One hundred Ukrainians have already received specialized military training in the city of Peja. A welcome knowledge transfer between two countries marked by war.

title: Germany: Several people killed in Hamburg church shooting
description: Police did not give an exact toll on the number of deaths, but several German national media said at least six people were killed.

title: One dead, two wounded in Tel Aviv shooting hours after West Bank raid
description: This year has been marked by escalating unrest across the West Bank, as Israeli arrest raids spiral into protracted firefights with armed Palestinians.

title: In Ukraine, history lessons become a national security issue
description: Ukraine's government has created a task force to change its school curriculum and combat Russian propaganda. Teachers on the force are rewriting the history sections in Ukraine's textbooks, with words like 'war,' 'Putinism,' and 'collaboration' appearing.

title: Marseille's MuCEM revisits the history of Egyptian city Alexandria
description: The exhibition 'Alexandria: Past Futures' transports visitors between past and present to deconstruct the myth of the ancient Egyptian city, but without erasing it.

title: Tens of thousands continue protesting in Georgia despite government backtrack on controversial bill
description: Tens of thousands took to the streets in Georgia this week after lawmakers initially backed the 'foreign agents' bill. Protests have continued despite the bill being withdrawn.

title: Russia, UN set for Ukraine grain deal renewal talks
description: The UN and Turkey-brokered Black Sea Grain Initiative helped ease the global food crisis caused by Russia's invasion. It will automatically renew on March 18 unless Moscow or Kyiv object.

title: Paris Olympics chief defends ticket pricing after criticism
description: Around 3.25 million tickets have been sold over the last month, around a third of the total, but the release has been overshadowed by criticism of the costs.

title: Berlin to let everyone go topless at public swimming pools
description: A woman filed a discrimination complaint after she was told she could not go topless in a public swimming pool in Berlin.

title: In Brazil, Lula takes his first difficult steps
description: Two months after his inauguration the president's popularity has plateaued. In addition to sluggish growth prospects, his government is facing its first public fault.

title: Pentagon chief says US 'disturbed' by West Bank settler violence
description: On a visit to Israel, United States Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin voiced concern over "settlement expansion and inflammatory rhetoric."

title: Denmark bets on CO2 storage to cut emissions
description: Inaugurated on Wednesday, the country's first landfill in the North Sea is expected to store 8 million tons of carbon dioxide per year by 2030.

title: Greece train crash: Pressure mounts on PM Mitsotakis' government
description: On Wednesday, March 8, over 65,000 people took to the streets in Greece to express their anger against the conservative government in the biggest protest since the economic crisis of the 2010s.

title: Biden sets up clash with Republicans on US budget
description: As national debt tops $31 trillion, US President Biden's budget proposals aim at emphasizing a contrast between two visions of society.

title: French women's football team coach Corinne Diacre fired
description: French coach since 2017, Diacre has been sacked following criticism from her players. Her successor has not been named.

title: 'Being a woman is considered a sin, even a crime, in Afghanistan'
description: The Afghan embassy in France does not recognize the Taliban regime. In an op-ed for 'Le Monde' for International Women's Day, Parwana Paikan calls on France to do more to help Afghanistan free itself from this repressive government.

title: Georgia's fragile European dream
description: The withdrawal of an anti-democratic bill on Thursday means pro-Europeans scored a crucial point. But Georgia's leaders have yet to prove their determination to join the European Union.

title: Macron's promise to include abortion in French Constitution is welcome, but the terms are worrying
description: The defenders of women's rights wanted an independent text, but the Elysée specified that it 'will be part of a constitutional revision.'

title: French pension reform: March 7 protests among largest since 1995
description: During the sixth day of action against President Macron's reform, 1.28 million marched across France according to the Interior Ministry.

title: In the Philippines, the lost children to online rape
description: 'Pedophilia online' (1/3). Sexual acts on minors ordered and watched live on the Internet by Europeans are committed mostly within families, where they constitute a source of income. This crime confronts the French, American and Filipino police forces with the challenges of international cooperation.

title: Georgian opposition calls for more protests against government
description: Tbilisi dropped a bill on 'foreign agents' that triggered massive protests earlier this week but opposition parties are calling for a new rally on Thursday evening.

title: Twitter hopes to return to profit despite outages and slipping image
description: CEO Elon Musk announced that drastic cuts in the company's payroll will enable it to break even.

title: Bezalel Smotrich, the extremist settler, is making his mark on the Israeli government
description: The leader of the Religious Zionist Party was entrusted by Benyamin Netanyahu with the administration of the occupied territories in the West Bank.

title: Paris 2024: France could recruit from French-speaking countries to bolster security during Olympic Games
description: The minister of sports and Olympic and Paralympic Games said that an option to address the shortage of private security workers was to 'look for complementary forces, perhaps in Francophone countries.'

title: War in Ukraine: Russian missiles target cities across Ukraine
description: Russian strikes targeting energy infrastructure were reported across Ukraine on Thursday, as fighting for control of the eastern city of Bakhmut raged on.

title: In Sweden, the dark legacy of 'Saturday candies'
description: Between 1947 and 1949, the Medical Agency subjected residents of an institution to extreme sugar consumption, an experiment that revealed a causal link with the development of cavities and led to the recommendation to eat sweets only once a week.

title: Colombia: First-ever indictments against ex-FARC fighters for child soldier recruitment
description: Ten former members of the guerilla group will face charges for allegedly recruiting minors into their ranks to help fight their bloody decades-long war against the state.

title: Senate votes to block DC crime laws with support of President Biden
description: The overhaul of DC's criminal code was approved late last year by the city council. It would redefine crimes, change criminal justice policies and rework how sentences should be handed down after convictions.

title: European Commission comes under 'Qatargate' spotlight
description: A senior Brussels official was gifted trips to Doha while his office was negotiating with the emirate.

title: US probes Tesla Autopilot and steering wheels that can come off
description: At least 14 Teslas have crashed into emergency vehicles nationwide while using the system.
